user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t *local;
    int                                 status;

    local = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_timebase_table, *token);

    pthread_cancel(local->handler_thread);

    /*
    ** Delete the timer
    */
    if (local->assigned_signal != 0)
    {
        status = timer_delete(local->host_timerid);
        if (status < 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error deleting timer: %s\n", strerror(errno));
            return OS_TIMER_ERR_INTERNAL;
        }

        local->assigned_signal = 0;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_TimeBaseDelete_Impl:
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t OS_impl_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_t       handler_thread;
    pthread_mutex_t handler_mutex;
    timer_t         host_timerid;
    int             assigned_signal;
    sigset_t        sigset;
    sig_atomic_t    reset_flag;
    struct timespec softsleep;
} OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_TIMER_ERR_INTERNAL (-32)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_DEBUG("Error deleting timer: %s\n", strerror(errno));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The code calls strerror(errno), which does not accept a pointer to a user buffer from which data would be copied; it returns a pointer to an internal, null-terminated string. The fragment does not call any of the buffer-manipulating <string.h> functions listed by MISRA 21.17 (e.g. strcpy, memcpy, strlen) with user pointers that could be overrun. Additionally, in the provided build the OS_DEBUG macro is defined empty, so the call is eliminated. (Note: strerror is not thread-safe on some systems, but that is a different concern and not a violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.)
